metadata.description: Manual J load calculations, heat loss/gain, BTU sizing

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Manual J load calculation?

choices.b: To properly size heating and cooling equipment

explanation.short: Manual J calculates building heating/cooling loads for proper equipment sizing.
explanation.detailed: ACCA Manual J is the industry standard for calculating residential heating and cooling loads. Its primary purpose is to determine the exact BTU/hr capacity needed so equipment is properly sized - not oversized or undersized. Oversized equipment short-cycles and fails to dehumidify; undersized equipment cannot maintain comfort.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference ACCA Manual J Section 1 - Purpose and Scope

questions.question: In Manual J, what does the outdoor design temperature represent?

choices.b: The extreme temperature expected 1% of the time

explanation.short: Design temperatures represent conditions exceeded only 1% of hours annually.
explanation.detailed: Manual J outdoor design temperatures are based on ASHRAE weather data representing conditions that are exceeded only 1% of the hours during the heating or cooling season. This provides a reasonable balance between equipment capacity and cost - designing for absolute extremes would result in oversized, inefficient equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Table 1A and Section 2 - Outdoor Design Conditions

questions.question: What is the standard indoor design temperature for heating load calculations?

explanation.short: 70°F is the standard indoor heating design temperature per Manual J.
explanation.detailed: Manual J specifies 70°F as the standard indoor design temperature for heating calculations. This represents normal comfort conditions during winter. While occupants may prefer slightly different temperatures, 70°F provides a consistent baseline for equipment sizing calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 2 - Indoor Design Conditions

questions.question: What is the standard indoor design temperature for cooling load calculations?

explanation.short: 75°F is the standard indoor cooling design temperature per Manual J.
explanation.detailed: Manual J specifies 75°F as the standard indoor design temperature for cooling calculations. This is slightly higher than heating because people wear lighter clothing in summer and tolerate slightly warmer conditions. The 5°F difference between heating (70°F) and cooling (75°F) design temperatures is industry standard.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 2 - Indoor Design Conditions

questions.question: What unit is used to express heating and cooling loads in residential HVAC?

choices.b: BTU/hr

explanation.short: BTU/hr (British Thermal Units per hour) is the standard unit for HVAC loads.
explanation.detailed: In the United States, heating and cooling loads are expressed in BTU/hr (British Thermal Units per hour). One BTU is the heat required to raise one pound of water by 1°F. Equipment capacity is rated in BTU/hr for heating and tons (12,000 BTU/hr = 1 ton) for cooling.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 3 - Load Calculation Fundamentals

questions.question: How many BTU/hr equals one ton of cooling capacity?

choices.b: 10,000 BTU/hr

explanation.short: One ton of cooling equals 12,000 BTU/hr.
explanation.detailed: One ton of refrigeration/cooling capacity equals 12,000 BTU/hr. This unit originated from the cooling effect of melting one ton of ice over 24 hours. A 3-ton air conditioner has 36,000 BTU/hr cooling capacity. This conversion is essential for equipment selection.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference HVAC fundamentals - standard industry conversion

questions.question: What is the relationship between R-value and U-factor?

choices.b: R-value = 1 / U-factor

explanation.short: R-value is the reciprocal of U-factor (R = 1/U).
explanation.detailed: R-value (thermal resistance) and U-factor (thermal transmittance) are reciprocals: R = 1/U and U = 1/R. R-value measures resistance to heat flow (higher is better insulation). U-factor measures heat transfer rate (lower is better insulation). A wall with R-20 insulation has a U-factor of 0.05.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 4 - Construction Tables and thermal resistance calculations

questions.question: Which component typically has the highest U-factor (poorest insulation) in a typical home?

choices.b: Windows

explanation.short: Windows typically have the highest U-factor (poorest insulation value).
explanation.detailed: Windows have much higher U-factors than insulated assemblies. A typical double-pane window has a U-factor around 0.30-0.50, while an insulated wall might be 0.05-0.07. This makes windows a significant source of heat loss/gain. Manual J assigns HTM (Heat Transfer Multiplier) values that reflect these differences.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 5 and window/wall HTM tables

questions.question: Calculate the heat loss through a wall: Area = 200 sq ft, U-factor = 0.05, Temperature difference = 60°F.

choices.b: 600 BTU/hr

explanation.detailed: Heat transfer formula: Q = U × A × ΔT, where Q = heat transfer (BTU/hr), U = U-factor, A = area (sq ft), ΔT = temperature difference (°F). Calculation: 0.05 × 200 × 60 = 600 BTU/hr. This is the fundamental equation for calculating conductive heat loss through building components.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply heat transfer formula Q = U × A × ΔT from Manual J Section 6

questions.question: In Manual J, what does HTM stand for?

choices.b: Heat Transfer Multiplier

explanation.short: HTM stands for Heat Transfer Multiplier.
explanation.detailed: HTM (Heat Transfer Multiplier) is a value from Manual J tables that combines U-factor and design temperature difference into a single multiplier. To calculate load: BTU/hr = Area × HTM. HTM values are provided for various construction types and design conditions, simplifying calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Table 4 and Section 6 - HTM explanation

questions.question: What is the difference between sensible heat and latent heat?

choices.a: Sensible heat is measured, latent heat is estimated
choices.b: Sensible heat changes temperature, latent heat changes moisture content
choices.c: Sensible heat applies to heating, latent heat applies to cooling
choices.d: Sensible heat is indoor, latent heat is outdoor

explanation.short: Sensible heat changes temperature; latent heat changes moisture (humidity).
explanation.detailed: Sensible heat causes temperature change that can be measured with a thermometer. Latent heat is associated with moisture change (humidity) without temperature change - the energy required to evaporate or condense water. Air conditioning must remove both sensible heat (temperature) and latent heat (humidity) for comfort.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 7 - Sensible and Latent Loads

questions.question: What is the typical sensible heat ratio (SHR) for residential cooling in a humid climate?

explanation.short: Humid climates typically have SHR of 0.70-0.80, indicating significant latent load.
explanation.detailed: Sensible Heat Ratio (SHR) = Sensible Load / Total Load. In humid climates, the SHR is typically 0.70-0.80, meaning 20-30% of the cooling load is latent (humidity). Dry climates may have SHR of 0.85-0.95. Properly sized equipment must match the building's SHR to provide adequate dehumidification.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 7 - Regional humidity considerations

questions.question: In Manual J, infiltration load is based on which of the following?

choices.b: Number of windows and doors only

explanation.short: Infiltration is based on construction tightness (ACH) and building volume.
explanation.detailed: Manual J calculates infiltration load based on the air changes per hour (ACH) rate and building volume. ACH depends on construction tightness - tight construction (0.25-0.35 ACH), average (0.35-0.50 ACH), or loose (0.50-0.75 ACH). The infiltration load = Volume × ACH × temperature factor.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 8 and Table 5A - Infiltration Procedures

questions.question: A house has 15,000 cubic feet of volume. At 0.5 ACH, how much air infiltrates per hour?

choices.b: 7,500 cubic feet

explanation.short: Volume × ACH = 15,000 × 0.5 = 7,500 cubic feet per hour
explanation.detailed: Infiltration volume = Building Volume × ACH (Air Changes per Hour). With 15,000 cu ft volume and 0.5 ACH: 15,000 × 0.5 = 7,500 cubic feet of outdoor air infiltrating per hour. This air must be heated or cooled to indoor conditions, creating the infiltration load.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply infiltration formula: Volume × ACH from Manual J Section 8

questions.question: Calculate the heating infiltration load: 8,000 CFH infiltration, outdoor temp 10°F, indoor temp 70°F. (Use 1.08 × CFM × ΔT)

choices.b: 8,640 BTU/hr

explanation.detailed: First convert CFH to CFM: 8,000 ÷ 60 = 133.3 CFM. Then apply sensible heat formula: Q = 1.08 × CFM × ΔT. Temperature difference: 70 - 10 = 60°F. Calculation: 1.08 × 133.3 × 60 = 8,638 BTU/hr (rounded to 8,640). The 1.08 factor accounts for air density and specific heat.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply sensible heat formula from Manual J Section 8

questions.question: Which window orientation produces the highest solar heat gain in summer?

choices.b: East-facing

explanation.short: West-facing windows produce the highest summer solar gain due to afternoon sun angle.
explanation.detailed: West-facing windows receive direct afternoon sun when outdoor temperatures are already at their daily peak, creating the highest combined solar and conductive gain. East windows get morning sun when it's cooler. South windows receive less direct summer sun due to high sun angle. North windows receive minimal direct sun year-round.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 9 and Table 6 - Solar Heat Gain

questions.question: What is SHGC and how does it affect cooling loads?

choices.a: Solar Heat Gain Coefficient - higher values increase cooling loads
choices.b: Solar Heat Gain Coefficient - lower values increase cooling loads
choices.c: Shade Height Glass Clearance - affects daylighting
choices.d: Standard Heating Gain Calculation - used for heating only

explanation.short: SHGC (Solar Heat Gain Coefficient) indicates how much solar heat passes through - higher = more gain.
explanation.detailed: SHGC (Solar Heat Gain Coefficient) ranges from 0 to 1 and indicates the fraction of solar radiation that enters through a window. Higher SHGC means more solar heat gain, increasing cooling loads. Low-E windows with low SHGC (0.25-0.35) reduce cooling loads; clear glass has SHGC around 0.85.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 9 and window specifications

questions.question: Which of the following is considered an internal heat gain for cooling calculations?

choices.b: Infiltration of outdoor air

explanation.short: Internal gains come from occupants, lighting, and appliances inside the home.
explanation.detailed: Internal heat gains originate from sources inside the building: occupants (sensible and latent heat from metabolism), lighting, cooking appliances, electronics, and other equipment. These add to the cooling load. Manual J provides default values for residential internal gains based on occupancy and appliance use.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 10 and Table 7 - Internal Gains

questions.question: What is the typical sensible heat gain per person used in residential Manual J calculations?

choices.b: 230 BTU/hr

explanation.short: Manual J uses approximately 230 BTU/hr sensible heat gain per person.
explanation.detailed: Manual J assigns about 230 BTU/hr sensible heat and 200 BTU/hr latent heat per person for residential calculations (assuming sedentary activity). Total is approximately 430 BTU/hr per person. Commercial calculations use higher values for increased activity levels.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Table 7 - Internal Gains per Occupant

questions.question: Why do ducts in an unconditioned attic add to the cooling load?

choices.b: Heat transfers from the hot attic into the cool supply air

explanation.short: Hot attic air heats up cool supply air in ducts, requiring additional cooling capacity.
explanation.detailed: When cooling ducts run through an unconditioned attic (which can reach 130-150°F), heat transfers from the hot attic into the cool supply air (typically 55°F). This duct gain can add 15-30% to the cooling load. Manual J includes duct loss/gain factors based on location and insulation level.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 11 - Duct Gains and Losses

questions.question: According to ACCA standards, cooling equipment should be sized at what percentage of the calculated cooling load?

explanation.short: ACCA Manual S recommends cooling equipment be sized 100-115% of Manual J load.
explanation.detailed: ACCA Manual S specifies that cooling equipment should not exceed 115% of the Manual J calculated load. Slight oversizing (up to 15%) is acceptable to allow for equipment availability in standard sizes. Significant oversizing causes short-cycling, poor dehumidification, and reduced equipment life.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference ACCA Manual S - Equipment Selection Guidelines

questions.question: What problems result from oversized cooling equipment?

choices.b: Short cycling and poor humidity control

explanation.short: Oversized equipment short-cycles and cannot properly dehumidify.
explanation.detailed: Oversized cooling equipment causes: (1) Short-cycling - unit turns on/off frequently, reducing efficiency and equipment life. (2) Poor dehumidification - unit doesn't run long enough to remove latent heat (humidity). (3) Temperature swings - rapid on/off causes comfort issues. (4) Higher energy costs despite shorter run times.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference ACCA Manual S - Effects of Improper Sizing

questions.question: Heating equipment sizing allows for greater oversizing than cooling. What is the maximum acceptable range?

explanation.short: Heating equipment can be sized up to 140% of calculated load per Manual S.
explanation.detailed: Manual S allows heating equipment to be sized up to 140% of the calculated heating load. This is more lenient than cooling (115%) because: (1) Heating doesn't involve dehumidification concerns. (2) Additional capacity provides faster warm-up recovery. (3) Fuel-fired equipment has minimum firing rates that limit oversizing effects.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference ACCA Manual S - Heating Equipment Sizing Guidelines

questions.question: Why is a room-by-room load calculation important?

choices.b: It determines proper airflow distribution to each room
choices.d: It's only needed for commercial buildings

explanation.short: Room-by-room loads determine proper airflow (CFM) for each room.
explanation.detailed: Room-by-room load calculations determine the CFM of conditioned air each room requires. This ensures proper duct sizing (Manual D) so every room receives adequate heating and cooling. Without room-by-room analysis, some rooms may be too hot or cold while others are comfortable.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 13 - Room-by-Room Loads and Manual D

questions.question: A room has a 6,000 BTU/hr cooling load. Using 400 CFM per ton, what airflow is needed?

choices.b: 200 CFM

explanation.detailed: First convert BTU/hr to tons: 6,000 ÷ 12,000 = 0.5 tons. Then apply CFM per ton: 0.5 × 400 = 200 CFM. The 400 CFM per ton is a standard rule of thumb for cooling airflow, though actual requirements vary based on sensible heat ratio and equipment specifications.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply CFM calculation: (BTU/hr ÷ 12,000) × 400 CFM/ton

questions.question: What is the typical CFM per ton range for residential cooling systems?

choices.b: 350-450 CFM per ton

explanation.short: Residential cooling typically uses 350-450 CFM per ton of capacity.
explanation.detailed: Residential AC systems typically operate at 350-450 CFM per ton, with 400 CFM/ton being the most common design point. Lower CFM (350) provides more dehumidification but less sensible cooling. Higher CFM (450) provides more sensible cooling but less dehumidification. The optimal rate depends on the sensible heat ratio.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 14 and equipment specifications

questions.question: What components make up the building envelope for load calculations?

choices.b: Walls, ceiling, floor, windows, and doors

explanation.short: Building envelope includes all surfaces separating conditioned from unconditioned space.
explanation.detailed: The building envelope includes all components separating conditioned indoor space from outdoors or unconditioned space: exterior walls, ceiling/roof, floor (if over unconditioned space), windows, doors, and below-grade walls. Each component has heat transfer characteristics (U-factors) used in load calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 4 - Building Envelope Components

questions.question: How are below-grade basement walls treated differently in heating vs cooling calculations?

choices.a: They're treated the same in both
choices.b: Below-grade walls contribute to heating load but not cooling
choices.c: Below-grade walls contribute to cooling load but not heating
choices.d: Below-grade walls are ignored in all calculations

explanation.short: Below-grade walls contribute to heating load but provide cooling benefit (not added to cooling load).
explanation.detailed: Below-grade basement walls and floors are in contact with earth at relatively stable temperatures (50-60°F typically). In winter, heat is lost to the cooler ground (heating load). In summer, the cool ground actually helps reduce cooling load, so below-grade surfaces are typically not added to summer cooling calculations or may be credited.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 15 and Table 8 - Below-Grade Calculations

questions.question: When sizing a heat pump, which load typically determines the equipment size?

choices.b: Always the cooling load
choices.c: The larger of heating or cooling loads
choices.d: The smaller of heating or cooling loads

explanation.short: Heat pumps are typically sized based on cooling load to prevent oversizing for cooling.
explanation.detailed: Heat pumps are typically sized to match the cooling load because oversized cooling causes poor dehumidification and short-cycling. If the heating load exceeds the heat pump capacity at design conditions, supplemental electric resistance heat (aux heat) makes up the difference. This is called the balance point approach.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 16 and Manual S - Heat Pump Sizing

questions.question: What is the 'balance point' for a heat pump system?

choices.a: The outdoor temperature where heating and cooling loads are equal
choices.b: The outdoor temperature where heat pump capacity equals heating load
choices.d: The point where indoor and outdoor temperatures are equal

explanation.short: Balance point is where outdoor temperature makes heat pump capacity equal to building heating load.
explanation.detailed: The balance point is the outdoor temperature at which the heat pump's heating capacity exactly equals the building's heating load. Above this temperature, the heat pump handles 100% of heating. Below it, supplemental heat is required. Heat pump capacity decreases as outdoor temperature drops, while heating load increases.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 16 - Heat Pump Balance Point

questions.question: According to ASHRAE 62.2, what determines minimum whole-house ventilation rate?

choices.b: Floor area and number of bedrooms

explanation.short: ASHRAE 62.2 bases whole-house ventilation on floor area plus number of bedrooms.
explanation.detailed: ASHRAE Standard 62.2 calculates required whole-house ventilation as: CFM = 0.03 × floor area + 7.5 × (bedrooms + 1). This accounts for both building size (pollutant sources from materials) and expected occupancy (based on bedroom count). This ventilation load must be included in load calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference ASHRAE 62.2 Section 4 and Table 4.1a

questions.question: Calculate ASHRAE 62.2 ventilation for a 2,000 sq ft home with 3 bedrooms.

choices.b: 75 CFM

explanation.detailed: ASHRAE 62.2 formula: CFM = 0.03 × floor area + 7.5 × (bedrooms + 1). Calculation: (0.03 × 2,000) + 7.5 × (3 + 1) = 60 + 30 = 90 CFM. The +1 assumes one more occupant than bedrooms. This is the minimum continuous whole-house ventilation requirement.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply ASHRAE 62.2 formula from Section 4

questions.question: How does high altitude affect HVAC load calculations and equipment capacity?

choices.a: No effect on loads or capacity
choices.b: Loads increase, capacity stays the same
choices.c: Air density decreases, reducing effective equipment capacity

explanation.short: High altitude means lower air density, reducing effective heating/cooling capacity.
explanation.detailed: At higher altitudes, air density decreases (about 3% per 1,000 ft). Lower density means less mass flow through equipment at the same CFM, reducing effective capacity. Equipment must be derated for altitude. For example, at 5,000 ft, capacity may be reduced 15-18%. Manual J includes altitude correction factors.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Appendix - Altitude Corrections

questions.question: A home has the following cooling loads: Envelope 24,000 BTU/hr, Internal gains 4,000 BTU/hr, Infiltration 3,600 BTU/hr, Duct gains 3,400 BTU/hr. What is the total cooling load?

choices.b: 31,600 BTU/hr

explanation.detailed: Total cooling load is the sum of all components: Envelope (walls, ceiling, windows, etc.) 24,000 + Internal gains (occupants, appliances) 4,000 + Infiltration (air leakage) 3,600 + Duct gains (from unconditioned spaces) 3,400 = 35,000 BTU/hr, or approximately 2.9 tons.
explanation.how_to_find: Sum all load components per Manual J Section 17

questions.question: A calculated cooling load is 42,000 BTU/hr. What is the maximum recommended equipment size?

choices.b: 3.5 tons (42,000 BTU/hr)

explanation.detailed: Manual S limits cooling equipment to 115% of calculated load. 42,000 × 1.15 = 48,300 BTU/hr maximum. A 4-ton unit (48,000 BTU/hr) is 48,000/42,000 = 114%, which is acceptable. A 4.5-ton unit would be 54,000/42,000 = 129%, exceeding the 115% limit.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply 115% maximum sizing rule from Manual S

questions.question: What R-value range is typical for attic insulation in climate zones 4-5?

choices.b: R-38 to R-49

explanation.short: Climate zones 4-5 typically require R-38 to R-49 attic insulation per IECC.
explanation.detailed: The IECC (International Energy Conservation Code) specifies minimum insulation levels by climate zone. Zones 4-5 (moderate climates) require R-38 to R-49 for attic/ceiling insulation. Colder zones (6-8) require R-49 to R-60. Warmer zones (1-3) may require R-30 to R-38. Manual J uses these values in load calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IECC Table R402.1.2 or Manual J Table 4A

questions.question: How does thermal mass (heavy construction) affect peak cooling loads?

choices.b: Decreases and delays peak loads
choices.c: Has no effect on peak loads

explanation.short: Thermal mass stores heat, reducing and delaying peak cooling loads.
explanation.detailed: Heavy construction materials (concrete, masonry, adobe) have thermal mass that absorbs heat during the day and releases it later. This reduces and delays peak cooling loads, potentially shifting them past the utility peak period. Manual J provides separate HTM values for lightweight vs. heavyweight construction to account for this effect.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 4 - Thermal Mass and Construction Types

questions.question: What is a 'block load' in HVAC terminology?

choices.a: The load from a single room
choices.b: The total load for an entire building or zone
choices.c: The load from concrete block construction
choices.d: The design load for equipment blocking

explanation.short: Block load is the total combined load for an entire building or zone.
explanation.detailed: Block load refers to the total combined heating or cooling load for an entire building or served zone. It's the sum of all room loads and is used for equipment sizing. Block load accounts for load diversity - not all rooms peak at the same time - which is why block load may be less than the sum of individual room peak loads.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 17 - Block Load Calculations

questions.question: Why might the whole-house cooling load be less than the sum of all room peak loads?

choices.b: Different rooms peak at different times (load diversity)
choices.c: Duct losses compensate for room loads
choices.d: Internal gains are subtracted at whole-house level

explanation.short: Rooms peak at different times - east rooms in morning, west rooms in afternoon.
explanation.detailed: Load diversity occurs because different rooms experience peak loads at different times. East-facing rooms peak in the morning with rising sun; west-facing rooms peak in the afternoon. Since these peaks don't coincide, the building's peak load (block load) is less than if all rooms peaked simultaneously. Manual J accounts for this with different peak times.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 17 - Load Diversity and Peak Times

questions.question: What is a Heating Degree Day (HDD)?

choices.a: The number of days heating is required
choices.b: The difference between 65°F and average daily temperature, summed over the heating season
choices.c: The maximum heating load day of the year
choices.d: The HVAC equipment run time in hours

explanation.short: HDD = sum of (65°F - average daily temp) for all days below 65°F.
explanation.detailed: Heating Degree Days measure heating demand over a season. For each day with average temperature below 65°F, HDD = 65 minus average temp. These are summed for the heating season. A location with 5,000 HDD needs more heating capacity than one with 3,000 HDD. While not directly used in Manual J, HDD helps estimate annual heating costs.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Appendix or ASHRAE weather data

questions.question: Calculate heating load for a wall: 400 sq ft, R-13 insulation, indoor temp 70°F, outdoor design temp -5°F.

choices.b: 2,308 BTU/hr

explanation.detailed: First find U-factor: U = 1/R = 1/13 = 0.077. Temperature difference: 70 - (-5) = 75°F. Apply heat loss formula: Q = U × A × ΔT = 0.077 × 400 × 75 = 2,308 BTU/hr. Note: This is a simplified calculation; actual wall U-factor includes air films and framing factors.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply Q = U × A × ΔT formula from Manual J Section 6

questions.question: What is the design temperature difference (ΔT) for heating if indoor design is 70°F and outdoor design is 5°F?

explanation.short: ΔT = Indoor - Outdoor = 70°F - 5°F = 65°F
explanation.detailed: Temperature difference (ΔT) is simply indoor design temperature minus outdoor design temperature. For heating: ΔT = 70 - 5 = 65°F. This ΔT is used in all heat loss calculations through the building envelope. Larger ΔT means greater heat loss and higher heating load.
explanation.how_to_find: Subtract outdoor from indoor design temperature per Manual J Section 2

questions.question: How does low-E coating affect window heat transfer?

choices.b: Reduces SHGC only
choices.d: Increases heat transfer for solar gain

explanation.short: Low-E coating reduces both conductive heat transfer (U-factor) and solar heat gain (SHGC).
explanation.detailed: Low-emissivity (Low-E) coatings are microscopically thin metal layers that reflect radiant heat. They reduce the U-factor (improving insulation value) and typically reduce SHGC (blocking solar heat gain). Different Low-E coatings are available - high solar gain for cold climates, low solar gain for hot climates.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 5 - Window Performance Values

questions.question: How is heat loss calculated for a slab-on-grade foundation?

choices.a: Based on slab area times U-factor
choices.b: Based on slab perimeter length
choices.d: Slab heat loss is typically ignored

explanation.short: Slab-on-grade heat loss is calculated based on perimeter length, not area.
explanation.detailed: For slab-on-grade foundations, most heat loss occurs at the edge (perimeter) where the slab meets outdoor conditions. Heat loss is calculated using perimeter length × F-factor (BTU/hr per linear foot per °F ΔT). The center of the slab loses little heat because soil temperatures are relatively stable. Perimeter insulation significantly reduces heat loss.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 15 and Table 8 - Slab Perimeter Factors

questions.question: When is a zoned HVAC system most beneficial?

choices.b: Multi-level homes or homes with varying loads in different areas
choices.c: Homes with all rooms having similar loads

explanation.short: Zoning benefits multi-level homes and those with varying loads between areas.
explanation.detailed: Zoned systems are most beneficial when different areas have different load profiles: multi-story homes (heat rises), homes with large sun-exposed rooms vs. shaded rooms, homes with occupied and unoccupied areas, or bonus rooms over garages. Zoning allows independent temperature control and avoids conditioning unoccupied spaces.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 18 and Manual Zr - Zoning Guidelines

questions.question: What does a blower door test measure?

choices.b: Building air leakage rate

explanation.short: Blower door tests measure building envelope air leakage (infiltration).
explanation.detailed: A blower door is a calibrated fan installed in an exterior door opening. It pressurizes or depressurizes the building (typically to 50 Pascals) while measuring airflow required to maintain that pressure. Results in CFM50 or ACH50 indicate building tightness. This data can refine infiltration estimates in Manual J calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 8 - Measured Infiltration Methods

questions.question: How does duct leakage affect load calculations?

choices.a: Duct leakage is not included in Manual J
choices.b: Leaky ducts in unconditioned spaces increase loads
choices.c: Duct leakage only affects cooling, not heating
choices.d: Leaky ducts decrease loads by providing ventilation

explanation.short: Duct leakage in unconditioned spaces loses conditioned air, increasing loads.
explanation.detailed: When ducts leak in unconditioned spaces (attic, crawlspace), conditioned supply air escapes and unconditioned air may be drawn in. This effectively increases the heating and cooling loads - equipment must compensate for lost capacity. Manual J includes duct loss factors that can add 15-30% to calculated loads for poorly sealed ducts.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 11 - Duct Loss Factors

questions.question: What must load calculation software comply with to be accepted as equivalent to Manual J?

choices.b: ACCA-approved software list

explanation.short: Software must be on the ACCA-approved list to be considered Manual J equivalent.
explanation.detailed: For load calculation software to be accepted as producing Manual J equivalent results, it must be on ACCA's approved software list. ACCA certifies that approved software follows Manual J methodology and procedures. Popular approved programs include Wrightsoft Right-J, Elite RHVAC, and CoolCalc. Non-approved software may not be accepted by code officials.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference ACCA website for approved software list and Manual J Section 1

questions.question: Why are 'rule of thumb' sizing methods (e.g., tons per square foot) discouraged?

choices.b: They don't account for actual building characteristics
choices.c: They're only accurate for commercial buildings

explanation.short: Rule of thumb methods ignore actual insulation, windows, orientation, and climate specifics.
explanation.detailed: Rule of thumb methods (like '1 ton per 500 sq ft') ignore crucial variables: insulation levels, window area and type, building orientation, local climate, infiltration, duct location, and internal gains. This typically results in oversized equipment, wasting money and causing comfort and humidity problems. Manual J accounts for all these factors.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 1 - Purpose of Proper Load Calculations

questions.question: According to IMC and IRC, when is a load calculation required?

choices.b: Only for commercial buildings
choices.c: For new equipment installation and major alterations

explanation.short: IMC and IRC require load calculations for new equipment installation and major alterations.
explanation.detailed: IMC Section 312.1 and IRC Section M1401.3 require heating and cooling equipment to be sized based on building load calculations per ACCA Manual J or equivalent. This applies to new construction, equipment replacement, and major alterations. Code officials may require load calculation documentation before issuing permits.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IMC 312.1 and IRC M1401.3 - Equipment Sizing Requirements

questions.question: What is the difference between direct and diffuse solar radiation?

choices.a: Direct comes from the sun; diffuse is reflected from clouds and sky
choices.b: Direct is summer; diffuse is winter
choices.c: Direct is morning; diffuse is afternoon

explanation.short: Direct radiation comes straight from the sun; diffuse is scattered by atmosphere, clouds, and reflections.
explanation.detailed: Direct solar radiation travels in a straight line from the sun. Diffuse radiation is scattered by clouds, atmosphere, and reflected from ground and surroundings. On overcast days, nearly all radiation is diffuse. Manual J accounts for both in window solar heat gain calculations, using different factors for direct and diffuse.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 9 - Solar Radiation Components

questions.question: A room is 15' × 20' with 10' ceilings. What is the volume for infiltration calculations?

choices.b: 3,000 cubic feet

explanation.short: Volume = Length × Width × Height = 15 × 20 × 10 = 3,000 cu ft
explanation.detailed: Room volume is calculated as Length × Width × Ceiling Height. For this room: 15 ft × 20 ft × 10 ft = 3,000 cubic feet. Volume is used for infiltration calculations - higher ceilings mean more volume and potentially more infiltration load. Cathedral ceilings or vaulted spaces significantly increase volume.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply volume formula from Manual J Section 3

questions.question: In Manual J, what is 'Daily Range' and why does it matter for cooling?

choices.b: The difference between daily high and low temperatures
choices.c: The distance equipment can be from a wall

explanation.short: Daily Range is the difference between typical daily high and low outdoor temperatures.
explanation.detailed: Daily Range (DR) is the difference between the typical daily high and low temperatures at a location - Low (<15°F), Medium (15-25°F), or High (>25°F). High daily range locations (like desert climates) have cooler nights, reducing cooling loads due to thermal mass effects. Manual J adjusts cooling HTM values based on daily range.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 2 and Table 1 - Daily Range Categories

questions.question: How do skylights compare to vertical windows in terms of solar heat gain?

choices.a: Skylights have less solar gain than vertical windows
choices.b: Skylights have the same gain as south-facing windows
choices.c: Skylights have significantly more solar gain than vertical windows
choices.d: Skylights only gain heat in winter

explanation.short: Skylights receive more direct solar radiation and have higher heat gain than vertical windows.
explanation.detailed: Skylights (horizontal or near-horizontal glazing) receive solar radiation from a larger portion of the sky dome and get direct summer sun when it's nearly overhead. This results in much higher solar heat gain than vertical windows - often 2-3 times more per square foot. Manual J provides higher HTM values for skylights, especially in cooling calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 5 and Table 5 - Skylight Heat Gain Factors

questions.question: Which type of window shading is most effective at reducing cooling loads?

choices.b: Interior drapes

explanation.short: Exterior shading blocks solar radiation before it enters the building.
explanation.detailed: Exterior shading (awnings, overhangs, exterior shutters) is most effective because it blocks solar radiation before it passes through the glass and enters the building. Interior shading (blinds, drapes) allows solar heat through the glass first, where it's partially trapped inside. Exterior shading can reduce solar gain by 50-80%.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 9 - Shading Effectiveness

questions.question: A south-facing window needs shading. Why is an overhang effective in summer but allows winter solar gain?

choices.a: The overhang is removable in winter
choices.b: Summer sun angle is higher; winter sun angle is lower
choices.c: Overhangs only work with Low-E glass
choices.d: Cloud cover is different by season

explanation.short: High summer sun is blocked by overhangs; low winter sun passes underneath.
explanation.detailed: The sun's angle changes seasonally. In summer, the sun is high in the sky (60-70° above horizon at noon), so a properly designed overhang blocks direct sunlight from south windows. In winter, the sun is low (20-30° above horizon), allowing solar radiation to pass under the overhang and enter the building, providing free heating.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 9 - Overhang Design for Solar Control

questions.question: How is a wall between a conditioned space and an attached garage treated in load calculations?

choices.a: Same as an exterior wall to outdoor conditions
choices.b: As semi-exterior with reduced temperature difference
choices.c: The wall is ignored in calculations
choices.d: Same as an interior wall between conditioned rooms

explanation.short: Garage walls are semi-exterior - temperature difference is less than full outdoor conditions.
explanation.detailed: An attached garage is typically semi-conditioned - not heated/cooled but somewhat protected from extreme outdoor temperatures. Manual J treats walls between conditioned space and garages as semi-exterior, using a reduced temperature difference (about 50-70% of outdoor ΔT) for load calculations. This accounts for the garage's buffering effect.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 15 - Semi-Conditioned Spaces

questions.question: What is thermal bridging and how does it affect load calculations?

choices.b: Increased heat transfer through framing members that bypass insulation
choices.c: Heat transfer between zones through doorways

explanation.short: Thermal bridging is heat transfer through structural members (studs, joists) that have lower R-value than insulation.
explanation.detailed: Thermal bridging occurs when building framing (wood studs, steel studs, joists) creates a path of lower thermal resistance than the surrounding insulation. A 2×6 wood stud has only about R-6.9 compared to R-19 cavity insulation. Manual J accounts for this with whole-wall U-factors that blend insulation and framing R-values.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 4 - Framing Factors and Whole-Wall Values

questions.question: What is fenestration ratio (window-to-wall ratio) and why is it important?

choices.a: The ratio of window frame to glass area
choices.b: The percentage of wall area that is glass/windows
choices.c: The ratio of east windows to west windows
choices.d: The number of windows per room

explanation.short: Fenestration ratio is the percentage of exterior wall area that is windows and glass doors.
explanation.detailed: Fenestration ratio is total window/glass door area divided by gross exterior wall area, typically expressed as a percentage. Higher ratios mean more solar gain and heat transfer. Energy codes often limit fenestration ratio (typically 15-25% for residential). High-performance glazing may allow higher ratios while meeting energy targets.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 5 and IECC glazing requirements

questions.question: Which activities contribute to latent (moisture) cooling loads in a residence?

choices.b: Heat transfer through walls

explanation.short: Latent loads come from moisture sources: people, cooking, bathing, and humid outdoor air infiltration.
explanation.detailed: Latent (moisture) loads come from: occupants (breathing, perspiration ~200 BTU/hr per person), cooking (boiling, dishwashing), bathing (showers, baths), and infiltration of humid outdoor air. Indoor plants and aquariums also add moisture. The AC system must remove this moisture in addition to sensible (temperature) heat.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 7 - Latent Load Sources

questions.question: In Manual J, what does 'grains difference' refer to in latent load calculations?

choices.a: The weight of water removed per hour
choices.b: The difference in moisture content between indoor and outdoor air
choices.c: The size of water droplets on the coil
choices.d: The grain structure of insulation materials

explanation.short: Grains difference is the moisture content difference between outdoor and indoor design conditions.
explanation.detailed: Moisture content in air is measured in grains (7,000 grains = 1 pound of water). The grains difference is outdoor humidity minus indoor design humidity. For example, if outdoor air is 105 grains/lb and indoor design is 50 grains/lb, the difference is 55 grains. This determines the latent load from infiltration and ventilation.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 7 and Table 1 - Moisture Conditions

questions.question: Using the sensible heat formula, calculate CFM needed for a 15,000 BTU/hr sensible load with a 20°F supply air temperature drop.

choices.b: 625 CFM

explanation.detailed: Sensible heat formula: BTU/hr = 1.08 × CFM × ΔT. Rearranged: CFM = BTU/hr ÷ (1.08 × ΔT). Calculation: 15,000 ÷ (1.08 × 20) = 15,000 ÷ 21.6 = 694.4 CFM, rounded to 695 CFM. The 1.08 factor accounts for air density and specific heat at standard conditions.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply sensible heat formula from Manual J Section 14

questions.question: What is the typical supply air temperature for a residential cooling system?

explanation.short: Residential AC systems typically supply air at 55-60°F.
explanation.detailed: Residential air conditioning systems typically deliver supply air at 55-60°F (about 15-20°F below room temperature). This provides adequate temperature drop for sensible cooling and keeps the coil cold enough for dehumidification. Supply temperatures below 55°F may overcool or cause condensation on ducts; above 60°F reduces dehumidification capability.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 14 - Supply Air Conditions

questions.question: A furnace has 100,000 BTU/hr input and 95% AFUE. What is the heating output?

choices.b: 90,000 BTU/hr

explanation.short: Output = Input × AFUE = 100,000 × 0.95 = 95,000 BTU/hr
explanation.detailed: AFUE (Annual Fuel Utilization Efficiency) indicates the percentage of fuel energy converted to usable heat over a heating season. Output = Input × AFUE. For this furnace: 100,000 × 0.95 = 95,000 BTU/hr output. The remaining 5% (5,000 BTU/hr) is lost through flue gases and casing.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply Output = Input × AFUE formula

questions.question: How many watts of electric resistance heat equals 3,413 BTU/hr?

choices.b: 1,000 watts

explanation.short: 1 kW = 3,413 BTU/hr; 3,413 BTU/hr = 1,000 watts
explanation.detailed: The conversion factor is 3,413 BTU/hr per kW (or 3.413 BTU/hr per watt). Electric resistance heat is 100% efficient, so 1,000 watts (1 kW) produces exactly 3,413 BTU/hr of heat output. This conversion is essential for sizing electric heating elements and comparing to gas/oil systems.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply conversion: 1 kW = 3,413 BTU/hr

questions.question: What is the typical temperature rise range for residential forced-air heating?

explanation.short: Furnace manufacturers specify temperature rise ranges of 35-65°F.
explanation.detailed: Temperature rise is the difference between return air and supply air temperatures. Manufacturers specify acceptable rise ranges, typically 35-65°F for gas furnaces. Too low a rise indicates excessive airflow (good for cooling but reduces heating efficiency). Too high indicates insufficient airflow (risk of overheating and limit switch tripping).
explanation.how_to_find: Reference furnace nameplate data and Manual J Section 14

questions.question: What minimum insulation is required for ducts in unconditioned attics per IECC?

explanation.short: IECC requires minimum R-8 duct insulation in unconditioned attics.
explanation.detailed: The IECC requires a minimum of R-8 insulation for supply ducts in unconditioned spaces (attics, crawlspaces, garages). Some climate zones or local codes may require higher values. Proper duct insulation reduces duct gains/losses that would otherwise increase equipment loads and operating costs.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IECC Section R403.3.1 - Duct Insulation

questions.question: How should ductless mini-split systems be sized compared to ducted systems?

choices.a: Larger, because they serve single zones
choices.b: Sized to room-by-room loads since they serve individual zones
choices.c: Same as ducted, using whole-house block load
choices.d: Always use manufacturer's square footage guidelines

explanation.short: Mini-splits are sized to individual room loads since each unit serves a specific zone.
explanation.detailed: Ductless mini-splits serve individual rooms or zones, so each indoor unit should be sized to its room's calculated heating and cooling load - not the whole-house block load. A multi-zone system with one outdoor unit serving multiple indoor units requires sizing each head unit appropriately and selecting an outdoor unit with sufficient total capacity.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 16 - Ductless System Sizing

questions.question: What indoor relative humidity range does Manual J target for summer comfort?

explanation.short: Manual J targets 50-60% indoor relative humidity for summer comfort.
explanation.detailed: Manual J specifies a design indoor condition of 50% relative humidity at 75°F for cooling calculations, with an acceptable comfort range of 50-60%. Higher humidity feels uncomfortable even at proper temperature and promotes mold growth. The cooling system's latent capacity must be adequate to maintain this humidity level.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 7 - Indoor Design Conditions

questions.question: In Manual J, what is an 'exposure factor' for windows?

choices.a: How much the window is exposed to wind
choices.b: A modifier based on window orientation and shading
choices.c: The percentage of glass in the window frame

explanation.short: Exposure factor adjusts solar gain based on window orientation and external shading.
explanation.detailed: Exposure factors in Manual J modify the solar heat gain calculation based on the window's cardinal orientation (N, S, E, W) and any external shading (overhangs, trees, neighboring buildings). A north window has a lower exposure factor than a west window. Shaded windows have reduced factors compared to unshaded.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 5 and Table 5 - Window Exposure Factors

questions.question: How is heat loss calculated for a floor over an unconditioned crawlspace?

choices.a: Based on floor area and outdoor design temperature
choices.b: Based on floor area using a reduced temperature difference
choices.c: Floor heat loss is typically ignored

explanation.short: Crawlspace floors use a reduced temperature difference since crawlspace isn't at outdoor temp.
explanation.detailed: Floors over unconditioned crawlspaces experience heat loss, but the crawlspace temperature is between indoor and outdoor (typically more moderate than outdoors). Manual J uses a reduced temperature difference or crawlspace temperature assumption based on crawlspace ventilation and insulation. Proper floor insulation (R-19 to R-30) significantly reduces this loss.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 15 and Table 8 - Floor Over Crawlspace

questions.question: When sizing for radiant floor heating, why might heating load calculations differ from forced-air systems?

choices.b: Radiant heating allows lower indoor air temperatures for equivalent comfort
choices.c: Radiant systems can't meet high loads

explanation.short: Radiant heating provides comfort at lower air temperatures because it heats surfaces and occupants directly.
explanation.detailed: Radiant floor heating warms surfaces and people directly through infrared radiation, not just air. This provides equivalent comfort at lower air temperatures (typically 2-4°F lower than forced air). Some designers reduce calculated heating loads by 5-10% for radiant systems, though conservative practice is to size for full Manual J load.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 16 - Radiant System Considerations

questions.question: Why do ducts in attics create larger load increases in summer than winter?

choices.b: Summer attic temperatures can exceed 130°F, creating extreme temperature differences
choices.d: Duct insulation only works in winter

explanation.short: Attic temperatures can reach 130-150°F in summer, creating huge temperature difference with 55°F supply air.
explanation.detailed: In summer, attic temperatures can reach 130-150°F from solar heating of the roof. With 55°F supply air in ducts, this creates a 75-95°F temperature difference driving heat into the duct. In winter, attic temperature is closer to outdoor temp (say 20°F) and supply air is around 120°F - only 100°F difference, and heating is less critical than dehumidification.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 11 - Duct Gain/Loss Factors

questions.question: What defines a 'conditioned space' for load calculation purposes?

choices.b: A space with intentional heating, cooling, or ventilation
choices.d: Spaces that meet energy code requirements

explanation.short: Conditioned space is any space that is intentionally heated, cooled, or supplied with ventilation air.
explanation.detailed: A conditioned space is one that is intentionally heated, cooled, or both - including spaces served by HVAC supply registers, radiant panels, or baseboards. Also includes spaces supplied with outdoor ventilation air. Load calculations determine the BTU/hr required to maintain comfort conditions in these spaces.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 3 and IECC definitions

questions.question: In a two-story home, the second floor typically has which characteristic?

choices.a: Higher heating load, lower cooling load
choices.b: Lower heating load, higher cooling load
choices.d: No heat transfer with first floor

explanation.short: Upper floors have lower heating loads (heat rises) but higher cooling loads (hot attic above, solar gain).
explanation.detailed: Upper floors typically have lower heating loads because heat rises from below (first floor provides heat). However, upper floors have higher cooling loads due to: ceiling heat gain from hot attic, potentially more direct solar gain, and heat stratification. This is why two-story homes often benefit from zoned systems.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 18 - Multi-Story Considerations

questions.question: Calculate total R-value for a wall assembly: R-0.17 outside air film, R-0.5 siding, R-0.5 sheathing, R-13 insulation, R-0.45 drywall, R-0.68 inside air film.

explanation.detailed: For series heat flow, R-values add directly. Total R = 0.17 (outside air) + 0.5 (siding) + 0.5 (sheathing) + 13 (insulation) + 0.45 (drywall) + 0.68 (inside air) = 15.30. Note this doesn't account for framing thermal bridging, which would reduce the effective whole-wall R-value.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply R-value addition from Manual J Section 4

questions.question: Why are air film resistances included in wall assembly R-value calculations?

choices.b: Still air layers at surfaces provide thermal resistance
choices.d: Air films are only used in winter calculations

explanation.short: Thin still air layers at surfaces provide measurable thermal resistance.
explanation.detailed: At every surface (inside and outside of walls, floors, ceilings), a thin layer of relatively still air exists that provides thermal resistance. The inside air film (R-0.68 for vertical surfaces) is larger than outside (R-0.17) because exterior wind reduces the boundary layer. These must be included for accurate U-factor calculation.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 4 and Table 4A - Air Film Resistances

questions.question: Compared to wood framing, how does steel framing affect wall thermal performance?

choices.a: Steel provides better insulation than wood
choices.b: No difference in thermal performance
choices.c: Steel creates significant thermal bridging, reducing effective R-value
choices.d: Steel only affects fire resistance, not thermal performance

explanation.short: Steel studs conduct heat much faster than wood, creating severe thermal bridging.
explanation.detailed: Steel has a thermal conductivity about 400 times greater than wood. Steel studs create severe thermal bridges that can reduce a wall's effective R-value by 40-50% compared to wood framing with same insulation. Manual J provides lower whole-wall R-values for steel-framed assemblies. Exterior continuous insulation is often required to mitigate steel thermal bridging.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 4 and Table 4B - Steel Framing Factors

questions.question: What is the benefit of continuous insulation (ci) on exterior walls?

choices.a: Adds R-value and eliminates thermal bridging through framing
choices.b: Only provides vapor barrier

explanation.short: Continuous insulation adds R-value and covers framing, eliminating thermal bridging.
explanation.detailed: Continuous insulation (rigid foam or mineral wool) installed over the exterior of framing provides uninterrupted R-value across the entire wall, eliminating thermal bridging through studs. For example, R-5 continuous insulation over R-13 cavity insulation provides better performance than R-19 cavity alone because the R-5 covers the studs. IECC requires ci in many climate zones.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 4 and IECC continuous insulation requirements

questions.question: How are exterior doors treated in load calculations?

choices.b: Calculated using door U-factor and area, similar to windows
choices.c: Only the glass portion is calculated
choices.d: Doors are included in wall area

explanation.short: Exterior doors have specific U-factors and are calculated separately like windows.
explanation.detailed: Exterior doors are treated similarly to windows - their area is calculated separately using the door's U-factor (typically 0.17-0.60 depending on construction). Insulated steel or fiberglass doors have lower U-factors than wood panel doors. Glass portions may have different U-factors and SHGC values than the solid portions.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 5 and Table 5 - Door Values

questions.question: How does an open-hearth fireplace affect heating load calculations?

choices.a: It reduces heating load by providing supplemental heat
choices.b: It increases infiltration significantly when damper is open
choices.c: It has no effect on heating calculations

explanation.short: Open fireplace dampers are a major source of infiltration, significantly increasing heating load.
explanation.detailed: An open fireplace damper allows substantial air to escape up the chimney - equivalent to leaving a window open. Even with damper closed, older fireplaces have significant leakage. Manual J includes additional infiltration allowance for fireplaces. Modern direct-vent gas fireplaces don't have this issue since they're sealed from the room.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 8 - Fireplace Infiltration

questions.question: How do kitchen and bathroom exhaust fans affect load calculations?

choices.a: They reduce loads by removing heat
choices.b: They create negative pressure, increasing infiltration and loads
choices.c: They have no effect on loads

explanation.short: Exhaust fans depressurize the building, drawing in unconditioned outdoor air.
explanation.detailed: Exhaust fans in kitchens and bathrooms remove indoor air, creating negative pressure that draws in unconditioned outdoor air through building cracks and openings. This infiltration must be heated or cooled. Manual J may include intermittent exhaust fan effects, though continuous whole-house ventilation is calculated separately per ASHRAE 62.2.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 10 and IMC 403 - Exhaust Requirements

questions.question: An indoor swimming pool primarily affects which type of load?

choices.b: Sensible cooling load only

explanation.short: Indoor pools contribute massive latent loads from continuous water evaporation.
explanation.detailed: Indoor pools are major sources of latent (moisture) load due to continuous evaporation from the water surface. This requires significant dehumidification capacity, often using dedicated pool dehumidifiers or specialized HVAC systems. The latent load can be 2-4 times the sensible load. Standard residential Manual J doesn't cover pools - specialized calculations are needed.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference specialized pool dehumidification guides and ASHRAE Handbook

questions.question: Why is humidification sometimes needed in winter in cold climates?

choices.a: Heating systems add too much moisture
choices.b: Cold outdoor air holds little moisture; when heated, relative humidity drops
choices.c: Building materials release moisture in winter
choices.d: Winter has more indoor moisture sources

explanation.short: Cold outdoor air contains little moisture; when heated to room temperature, its relative humidity becomes very low.
explanation.detailed: Cold air holds very little absolute moisture. When this dry outdoor air infiltrates and is heated to 70°F, its relative humidity can drop to 10-20%, causing discomfort, static electricity, and damage to wood. Humidifiers add moisture to maintain 30-40% winter indoor RH. This is a humidification load, separate from standard heating/cooling calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 7 - Winter Humidity Considerations

questions.question: Should equipment be oversized to allow for faster recovery from thermostat setback?

choices.b: Yes, use rule-of-thumb sizing to ensure quick recovery
choices.c: No, properly sized equipment handles recovery adequately
choices.d: Only gas furnaces need oversizing for setback

explanation.short: Properly sized equipment provides adequate recovery; oversizing causes other problems.
explanation.detailed: Equipment sized per Manual J and Manual S handles setback recovery adequately - it may take longer than oversized equipment, but comfort is maintained. Oversizing to speed recovery causes short-cycling, poor humidity control, and higher costs during normal operation. Smart thermostats can start recovery early to reach setpoint by desired time.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 12 and Manual S - Setback Considerations

questions.question: At what time of day does peak cooling load typically occur?

choices.b: Noon (12 PM)

explanation.short: Peak cooling load typically occurs mid-afternoon when outdoor temperature peaks and solar gain from west windows is highest.
explanation.detailed: Peak cooling load typically occurs between 3-5 PM when: (1) outdoor temperature reaches its daily maximum, (2) west-facing windows receive direct sun at a low angle (maximum penetration), (3) thermal mass has absorbed heat all day and is releasing it. This is why Manual J uses afternoon conditions for cooling design.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 9 - Peak Load Timing

questions.question: What is meant by 'coincident peak load' in load calculations?

choices.a: When heating and cooling loads are equal
choices.b: The sum of all individual room peak loads
choices.c: The building's peak load considering that different components peak at different times
choices.d: When electrical and HVAC peaks occur simultaneously

explanation.short: Coincident peak accounts for the fact that building components don't all peak at the same time.
explanation.detailed: The coincident peak load is the actual building peak when accounting for time diversity - east rooms peak in morning, west in afternoon, internal gains are constant, etc. It's typically less than simply adding all component peaks (non-coincident sum). Manual J uses coincident peak analysis for block load calculations to avoid oversizing.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 17 - Coincident Peak Methodology

questions.question: What ground temperature is typically assumed for basement floor heat loss calculations?

choices.b: 32°F (freezing)

explanation.short: Ground temperature below frost line is relatively stable at 50-60°F (varies by climate).
explanation.detailed: Below the frost line (4-6 feet in cold climates), ground temperature remains relatively constant year-round at approximately the annual average air temperature - typically 50-60°F in most U.S. locations. Manual J uses this stable ground temperature rather than outdoor air temperature for basement floor heat loss calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 15 and Table 8 - Ground Temperatures

questions.question: How do vapor barriers affect load calculations?

choices.a: Vapor barriers directly reduce heating loads
choices.b: Vapor barriers have no direct effect on loads but protect insulation effectiveness

explanation.short: Vapor barriers don't directly change loads but prevent moisture damage that could reduce insulation R-value.
explanation.detailed: Vapor barriers (or vapor retarders) don't directly affect load calculations - they don't add R-value or change heat transfer. However, they protect insulation from moisture accumulation. Wet insulation loses much of its R-value. Properly installed vapor barriers maintain insulation effectiveness assumed in Manual J calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 4 and IRC R702 - Vapor Retarders

questions.question: How should an enclosed sunroom (not conditioned) attached to the house be treated in load calculations?

choices.a: Include it in the conditioned floor area
choices.b: Ignore it completely
choices.c: Treat the wall between house and sunroom as semi-exterior
choices.d: Add its full glass area to the house's load

explanation.short: An unconditioned sunroom is a buffer zone - the common wall uses reduced temperature difference.
explanation.detailed: An unconditioned sunroom acts as a buffer space with temperatures between indoor and outdoor. The wall between the conditioned house and sunroom is treated as semi-exterior with reduced temperature difference for heat loss calculations. In cooling, the sunroom may actually be hotter than outdoors due to solar gain, potentially increasing loads.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 15 - Buffer Zones and Semi-Conditioned Spaces

questions.question: A location has 99% heating design temp of 5°F and 1% cooling design temp of 92°F. What do these percentiles mean?

choices.b: Temperature is above 5°F 99% of winter hours and below 92°F 99% of summer hours
choices.c: Only 1% of buildings need colder/hotter design temps
choices.d: Confidence levels in the data accuracy

explanation.short: 99% heating means outdoor temp is above 5°F for 99% of winter hours (only 1% colder); similar logic for cooling.
explanation.detailed: Design temperatures are based on percentiles of historical weather data. 99% heating design temp means the outdoor temperature is above this value 99% of winter hours - only 1% of hours are colder. Similarly, 1% cooling design means temperature exceeds this value only 1% of summer hours. This provides reasonable design conditions without designing for extreme events.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 2 and Table 1 - Design Condition Definitions

questions.question: How does ground-source (geothermal) heat pump load calculation differ from air-source?

choices.a: Geothermal uses different indoor design temperatures
choices.b: Building load calculation is the same; equipment selection considers ground loop capacity
choices.d: Ground temperature replaces outdoor design temperature

explanation.short: Building load calculation is identical; geothermal sizing considers ground loop heat exchange capacity.
explanation.detailed: The building's heating/cooling load is calculated the same way using Manual J - loads depend on the building, not the equipment type. However, geothermal equipment selection requires additional analysis of ground loop design (loop length, soil conductivity, ground temperature) using specialized methods like Manual GH to ensure the ground can accept/provide the required heat exchange.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 16 and ACCA Manual GH for geothermal

questions.question: A heat pump has a heating COP of 3.0. If the building needs 36,000 BTU/hr heating, how much electrical power is required?

explanation.short: COP 3.0 means 3 BTU heat output per 1 BTU electricity. 36,000 ÷ 3 = 12,000 BTU/hr = 3.5 kW
explanation.detailed: COP (Coefficient of Performance) is the ratio of heat output to electrical input. With COP of 3.0: Electrical input = Heat output ÷ COP = 36,000 BTU/hr ÷ 3 = 12,000 BTU/hr electrical input. Converting to kW: 12,000 ÷ 3,413 = 3.5 kW. This shows heat pumps are much more efficient than electric resistance heating.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply COP formula and kW conversion

questions.question: What construction tightness category should be used for a home with continuous air barrier and sealed penetrations?

choices.b: Average construction

explanation.short: Homes with continuous air barriers and sealed penetrations qualify as 'tight construction' in Manual J.
explanation.detailed: Manual J categorizes construction tightness as loose (older, unweatherized), average (standard modern construction), or tight (air barrier, sealed penetrations, verified with blower door). Tight construction has significantly lower infiltration rates (0.25-0.35 ACH vs 0.50-0.75 for loose), reducing heating/cooling loads.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 8 and Table 5A - Construction Tightness Categories

questions.question: Does Manual J include a safety factor in load calculations?

choices.a: Yes, a 15% safety factor is built in
choices.b: No, but one should be added by the contractor
choices.c: No, adding safety factors leads to oversizing
choices.d: Yes, a 25% safety factor for commercial properties

explanation.short: Manual J does not include safety factors; adding them causes oversizing problems.
explanation.detailed: Manual J calculations do not include safety factors, and ACCA explicitly warns against adding them. The procedures already incorporate appropriate assumptions (design conditions exceeded only 1% of time, standard construction factors, etc.). Adding safety factors leads to oversized equipment with all its associated problems. Manual S sizing limits (115% cooling, 140% heating) provide adequate margin.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 1 and Manual S - No Safety Factor Policy

questions.question: When performing a load calculation for equipment replacement in an existing home, what information is needed?

choices.b: Building dimensions, insulation levels, window types, and orientation

explanation.short: Full Manual J calculation requires building characteristics - not just square footage or old equipment size.
explanation.detailed: A proper load calculation for replacement equipment requires the same information as new construction: accurate building dimensions, insulation R-values in walls/ceiling/floor, window types and areas, orientation, construction tightness assessment, and duct location/condition. Old equipment size is unreliable - it may have been oversized originally.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 3 - Required Input Data

questions.question: How does a home energy rating (HERS) relate to Manual J load calculations?

choices.a: HERS replaces Manual J for new construction
choices.b: HERS ratings use Manual J calculations as a component
choices.d: HERS is only for commercial buildings

explanation.short: HERS ratings include Manual J-based heating and cooling loads as one component of the energy analysis.
explanation.detailed: Home Energy Rating System (HERS) evaluations for ENERGY STAR certification and code compliance include load calculations following Manual J methodology. The HERS software calculates heating and cooling loads to determine annual energy use. However, HERS also includes additional analysis (annual simulations, duct testing, envelope testing) beyond equipment sizing.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference RESNET standards and Manual J Section 1

questions.question: Manual J is designed for which type of buildings?

choices.b: High-rise residential only

explanation.short: Manual J covers single-family homes and small multifamily (up to about 10 units).
explanation.detailed: ACCA Manual J is specifically designed for residential buildings: single-family detached homes, townhouses, duplexes, and small multifamily buildings. Larger commercial and multifamily buildings use different methods (ASHRAE calculations, commercial software). Manual J assumptions about occupancy, schedules, and internal gains are residential-specific.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 1 - Scope and Application

questions.question: What documentation is typically required for code compliance when submitting load calculations?

choices.b: Complete load calculation printout showing inputs, assumptions, and results
choices.d: A verbal description of the calculation method

explanation.short: Code compliance typically requires complete documentation showing all inputs, assumptions, and calculated loads.
explanation.detailed: For permit approval, code officials typically require a complete load calculation report showing: building dimensions and construction details, insulation values used, window specifications, design conditions, infiltration assumptions, calculated room and block loads, and equipment selection. Software printouts or Manual J worksheets provide this documentation.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual J Section 19 and local code requirements (IMC 312)

questions.question: Which edition of Manual J is currently in use and referenced by energy codes?

choices.b: Manual J 7th Edition

explanation.short: Manual J 8th Edition is the current version referenced by IECC and IRC.
explanation.detailed: ACCA Manual J 8th Edition (2016) is the current version referenced by the International Energy Conservation Code (IECC) and International Residential Code (IRC). It updated weather data, added tables for newer construction types and window technologies, and improved procedures. Software claiming Manual J compliance must follow 8th Edition methodology.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IECC and IRC code references, ACCA publications

questions.code_reference: IECC, IRC, ACCA Manual J 8th Ed

questions.question: What is the specific heat of air at standard conditions used in HVAC calculations?

choices.b: 0.24 BTU/lb·°F

explanation.short: Air has a specific heat of approximately 0.24 BTU/lb·°F at standard conditions.
explanation.detailed: The specific heat of air at standard conditions is approximately 0.24 BTU/lb·°F. This value is used in sensible heat calculations. Combined with air density (0.075 lb/cu ft) and the 60 min/hr conversion, it yields the familiar factor 1.08 in the formula: BTU/hr = 1.08 × CFM × ΔT.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference HVAC fundamentals and psychrometric principles

questions.question: In the sensible heat formula Q = 1.08 × CFM × ΔT, what does the 1.08 factor represent?

choices.b: Air density × specific heat × 60 min/hr

explanation.short: 1.08 = air density (0.075 lb/cf) × specific heat (0.24 BTU/lb·°F) × 60 min/hr
explanation.detailed: The factor 1.08 in sensible heat calculations combines: air density at standard conditions (0.075 lb/cu ft) × specific heat of air (0.24 BTU/lb·°F) × 60 minutes per hour = 0.075 × 0.24 × 60 = 1.08. This converts CFM and temperature difference to BTU/hr. At high altitude, this factor decreases due to lower air density.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference HVAC fundamentals derivation of sensible heat formula

questions.question: What factor is used in the latent heat formula: Q = _____ × CFM × Δgr (grains difference)?

explanation.short: The latent heat formula uses 0.68: Q = 0.68 × CFM × Δgr
explanation.detailed: Latent heat formula: Q (BTU/hr) = 0.68 × CFM × Δgr, where Δgr is the difference in moisture content (grains per pound of dry air) between conditions. The 0.68 factor incorporates air density, the latent heat of vaporization of water (about 1,050 BTU/lb), and unit conversions.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference HVAC fundamentals - latent heat calculation

questions.question: Total cooling load is 48,000 BTU/hr with SHR of 0.75. What is the latent load?

choices.b: 16,000 BTU/hr

explanation.detailed: SHR (Sensible Heat Ratio) = Sensible Load / Total Load. Therefore: Sensible = Total × SHR = 48,000 × 0.75 = 36,000 BTU/hr. Latent = Total - Sensible = 48,000 - 36,000 = 12,000 BTU/hr. Or directly: Latent = Total × (1 - SHR) = 48,000 × 0.25 = 12,000 BTU/hr.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply SHR relationships: Sensible = Total × SHR; Latent = Total × (1-SHR)

questions.question: Calculate ventilation sensible cooling load: 100 CFM outdoor air, outdoor temp 95°F, indoor temp 75°F.

choices.b: 2,160 BTU/hr

explanation.detailed: Ventilation air must be cooled from outdoor to indoor conditions. Using the sensible heat formula: Q = 1.08 × CFM × ΔT = 1.08 × 100 × (95 - 75) = 1.08 × 100 × 20 = 2,160 BTU/hr sensible load. Latent load would be additional, calculated from grains difference.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply sensible heat formula for ventilation load

questions.question: What does EER measure for air conditioning equipment?

choices.b: Cooling capacity in BTU/hr per watt of electrical input at rated conditions
choices.c: The ratio of heating to cooling capacity

explanation.short: EER = Cooling BTU/hr ÷ Watts input, measured at specific rating conditions.
explanation.detailed: EER (Energy Efficiency Ratio) measures steady-state cooling efficiency: cooling output in BTU/hr divided by electrical input in watts, at ARI rating conditions (95°F outdoor, 80°F indoor DB/67°F WB). Higher EER means more efficient cooling. EER is a snapshot at one condition, while SEER accounts for seasonal variation.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference equipment specifications and DOE efficiency standards

questions.question: How does SEER differ from EER?

choices.a: SEER measures heating; EER measures cooling
choices.b: SEER is seasonal average efficiency; EER is steady-state at one condition
choices.c: SEER is for heat pumps only; EER is for air conditioners
choices.d: They are the same measurement with different units

explanation.short: SEER is seasonal average efficiency over a range of conditions; EER is steady-state at one test condition.
explanation.detailed: SEER (Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio) measures efficiency over a typical cooling season with varying outdoor temperatures and part-load operation. EER measures efficiency at a single steady-state condition. SEER is typically higher than EER because it includes mild conditions where equipment is more efficient. Minimum federal standards are set in SEER.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference DOE efficiency standards and AHRI rating procedures

questions.question: What efficiency rating is used for heat pump heating mode?

choices.b: AFUE

explanation.short: HSPF (Heating Seasonal Performance Factor) rates heat pump heating efficiency.
explanation.detailed: HSPF (Heating Seasonal Performance Factor) measures heat pump heating efficiency over a typical heating season, expressed as BTU of heat output per watt-hour of electricity. It accounts for varying outdoor temperatures, defrost cycles, and supplemental heat use. Higher HSPF means more efficient heating. Minimum federal standard is HSPF 8.8 for split systems.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference DOE efficiency standards for heat pumps

questions.question: In a dual-fuel system (heat pump + gas furnace), how is the changeover point determined?

choices.b: When heat pump efficiency drops below gas furnace efficiency
choices.c: At a fixed outdoor temperature set by manufacturer
choices.d: When the heat pump capacity equals the cooling load

explanation.short: Changeover occurs when heat pump operating cost exceeds furnace operating cost (based on efficiency and fuel prices).
explanation.detailed: The economic balance point for dual-fuel systems is where heat pump and furnace have equal operating costs. Below this outdoor temperature, the furnace is more economical. The balance point depends on heat pump efficiency at various outdoor temperatures, gas and electric prices, and furnace efficiency. It's typically calculated and programmed into the thermostat.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual S and utility rate analysis for dual-fuel balance point

questions.question: At what conditions is air conditioner cooling capacity typically rated?

choices.b: 85°F outdoor, 75°F indoor

explanation.short: Standard rating conditions are 95°F outdoor, 80°F indoor dry bulb/67°F wet bulb.
explanation.detailed: AHRI standard rating conditions for air conditioners are: 95°F outdoor dry bulb, 80°F indoor dry bulb, and 67°F indoor wet bulb. These represent typical peak cooling conditions. Actual capacity varies with conditions - it increases at milder outdoor temperatures and decreases at higher temperatures. Expanded performance data shows capacity at various conditions.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference AHRI Standard 210/240 rating conditions

questions.question: Why is expanded performance data important for equipment selection?

choices.b: It shows capacity at various conditions matching actual design conditions

explanation.short: Expanded data shows equipment performance at conditions other than standard rating, matching actual design conditions.
explanation.detailed: Equipment rated capacity is at standard conditions (95°F outdoor), but actual design conditions vary. Expanded performance data (from AHRI or manufacturer) shows sensible and total capacity at multiple outdoor temperatures and airflows. This allows selecting equipment that meets the calculated load at actual design conditions - crucial for proper humidity control.
